metadata.title: Diurnal thermal evaluation of an evacuated tube solar collector (ETSC) charged with graphene nanoplatelets-methanol nano-suspension

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Renewable Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/renene
Diurnal thermal evaluation of an evacuated tube solar collector (ETSC) charged with graphene nanoplatelets-methanol nano-suspension
M.M. Sarafraz a, *, M.R. Safaei b, c
a School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Adelaide, South Australia, Australia b Division of Computational Physics, Institute for Computational Science, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam c Faculty of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Ton Duc Thang University, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 21 February 2019 Received in revised form 26 March 2019 Accepted 18 April 2019 Available online 27 April 2019
Keywords: Nanofluid Evacuated tube Thermal efficiency Graphene nanoplatelets Heat pipe
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: mohammadmohsen.sarafraz@ade
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.renene.2019.04.091 0960-1481/© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
In the present article, we report the results of several experiments conducted on the thermal performance and efficiency of an evacuated tube solar collector (ETSC). The heat pipes were charged with graphene-methanol nanofluid and the effect of various operating conditions including the installation tilt angle of the collector, the value of the filling ratio, the mass fraction of graphene nanoplatelets and the flow rate of the collector's loop on the thermal efficiency of the collector was experimentally investigated. Results showed that the presence of graphene nanoplatelets improved the thermal conductivity of methanol (enhanced by 19% at wt. %¼ 0.1), while the heat capacity of the nanofluid decreased by a decrease in the mass fraction of the graphene (decreased by 4% at wt. %¼ 0.1). Also, it was identified that the thermal efficiency of the solar thermal collector reached 95% with nanofluid at wt. %¼ 0.1 and at flow rate of 3 lit/min. The largest temperature difference between the inlet and the outlet of the collector belonged to the graphene-methanol nanofluid at wt. %¼ 0.1, which represented the lowest heat capacity. Also, the daily thermal energy absorption of the collector was the highest at the tilt angle and the filling ratio values of 35 and 60%, respectively.
© 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Renewable energy is one of the potential solutions to address the challenges associated with the environmental pollution and climate change due to the combustion of fossil fuels [1]. With a continuous increase in the world population and also the limitation of the fossil fuels, special attention has recently been paid to renewable energy resources no only to address the energy crisis [2], but also to decrease the rate of emission of carbon dioxide and greenhouse gases to atmosphere. Solar thermal energy is by far one of the abundant energy resources, however, the intermittent behaviour of the solar energy together with a lack of a robust technology with high technology readiness level (TRL) are disadvantages associated with the use of solar thermal energy [3e6]. Hence, extensive research programs have been developed to harness the solar thermal energy in domestic and industrial sectors [4,7e9].
Solar thermal collectors are widely used in domestic and
laide.edu.au (M.M. Sarafraz).
industrial applications, which can provide thermal energy from solar irradiance for various applications [10,11]. Evacuated solar thermal collector is an apparatus, which uses the heat pipe technology to absorb the solar energy and transfer it to another heat transfer fluid using the phase change mechanism inside the heat pipe [6]. Each evacuated tube has an internal heat pipe, which is responsible to deliver the heat from the absorbance to the header tank. A heat pipe is a passive two-phase heat exchanging medium, consisting of three sections of evaporator, adiabatic and the condenser. In solar collectors, generally the condenser section is constantly cooled with water, while the evaporator section is heated up with solar irradiance. Hence, in the evaporator section, “convective boiling” is the dominant mechanism of heat transfer. Therefore, thermal performance of the heat pipe is relatively high in comparisonwith the convective systems [12]. This is because the bubble formation in the evaporator section not only enhances the heat transfer in the evaporator section but facilitates the phase change and the heat transfer throughout the adiabatic and the condenser sections. Interestingly, in the condenser, the dominant heat transfer mechanism is condensation and as a result, the heat transfer coefficient (HTC) is large for both the evaporator and the
condenser sections [13e16]. Working fluid inside the heat pipe is a key parameter, which determines the overall thermal performance (THP) of system. A working fluid with a low boiling temperature, high thermal conductivity and plausible thermal properties can increase the THP of the heat pipe and also the efficiency of the solar thermal collector. Nanofluid was first introduced by Aragon National Laboratory (ANL) [17], and so far, much effort has been made to utilise nanofluids in various thermal applications including solar thermal energy [12,18e20]. A nanofluid is a mixture of a conventional coolant such as water or alcohol mixed with conductive solid particles, which has higher thermal conductivity [21e25] over the base fluid [26e30]. For example, Dehaj et al. [31] used aqueous nanofluids to increase the THP of a solar thermal collector. The influence of the fluid flow rate (FR) of the MgO/water nanofluid within the collector together with the concentration of the dispersed particles on the efficiency of the collector was experimentally studied and it was found that the efficiency of the collector enhanced with an increase in the flow rate. Also, the efficiency of the solar collector was further improved with an increase in the concentration of MgO nanoparticles within the base fluid. In another study, Ziyadanogullari et al. [32] experimentally assessed the effect of various nanoparticles on the THP of a flat plate solar thermal collector. Nanoparticles including alumina, copper oxide and titania were dispersed in water at volumetric concentrations of 0.2e0.8% and the flow rate of the nanofluid was set to 250 l/hr. Using the ASHRAE 93-2003 standard, it was identified that the use of nanofluid can potentially increase the efficiency of the collector in comparison with water. Sharafeldin et al. [33] perform a study to measure the THP of an evacuated tube solar collector (ETSC) charged with WO3 aqueous nanofluid at vol% of 0.014, 0.028, and 0.042. They demonstrated that the temperature difference of the fluid can be increased up to 21% for the solar collector working with nanofluid at vol. %¼ 0.042. Also, the thermal efficiency of the system increased by 23% in comparison with the system working with water. The maximum thermal efficiency of the system was 72.8%. Caesium oxide was also identified as a plausible nanoparticle and was tested in an ETSC [34]. They prepared the nanofluids at mass fractions of 0.015, 0.025, and 0.035 and stabilised them by optimising the value of the zeta potential. The thermal performance of the ETSC was examined at various operating conditions and it was found that the temperature difference between the inlet and outlet ports of the collector and also the absorbed energy increase when nanofluids are used. The maximum efficiency of 34% was recorded for the system.
In a study conducted by Ozsoy et al. [9], several experiments were conducted to identify the thermal efficiency of a thermosyphon heat pipe with a potential to be used in a solar thermal collector. Silver-water nanofluid was employed in the heat pipe with the view to evaluate its potential application for a continuous operation inside the hat pipe. The silver nanoparticles were synthesised to ensure a longer stability. They found that the synthesised silver nanofluid can plausibly increase the efficiency of the solar collector by 20.7% and 40% in comparisonwith purewater and it was also identified that the use of silver-water nanofluid can provide better heat transfer rate and less heat loss within the system.
In a work reported by Sani et al. [35], the heat transfer characteristics of a novel working fluid including the dispersion of the functionalised graphene nanoplatelets (fGnP) in Havoline Premixed 50/50 base fluid was investigated with the aim to use a functionalised nanofluid in a solar absorber. They investigated the optical characteristics, stability and the rheological properties of the introduced working fluid and found that the addition of the nanoparticles can lead to a considerably higher sunlight absorption
in comparisonwith pure base fluid. Also, the Rheology experiments revealed a Newtonian behaviour in the shear rate range between 10 and 1000 s 1.
Based on the aforementioned literature, heat pipes and thermosyphons are the heart of the evacuated solar thermal collectors. Hence, improving the THP of the heat pipe directly affects the performance of the solar collector [36]. Hence, extensive studies has been conducted to better understand the effect of nanoparticles on THP of the heat pipes [37,38]. For instance, heat transfer characteristics of a heat pipe was evaluated by Nazari et al. [39] with the purpose to quantify the HTC and efficiency of the system working with a stabilised aqueous graphene oxide nanofluid at weight fractions of 0.25e1.5 gr/lit. It was revealed that graphene oxide can enhance the thermal conductivity and other thermo-physical properties of water together with a massive reduction in the THP of the heat pipe. The reduction in the THP was attributed to the viscosity augmentation. In another similar study conducted by Arya et al. [40], it was found that the carbon nanotube dispersed inwater has reasonably good thermal properties to improve the THP of a flat heat pipe. They fabricated the heat pipe using high-quality aluminium together with some fin pins installed on the condenser section to fortify the heat transfer rate from condenser to environment. Results showed that with an increase in the heat flux of the evaporator, the HTC increased, which was attributed to the change in the heat transfer regime. Also, they propose that the ratio of working fluid to the total volume of the heat pipe must be 0.8 in order to maximise the THP of the system. Vijayakumar et al. [41] investigated the potential application of CuO and alumina nanofluids in a heat pipe employed in a ETSC and found that the presence of the nanoparticles can decrease the temperature profile and suppress the heat transfer mechanism in the evaporator from boiling to evaporation, while decreasing the total thermal resistance of the heat pipe.
Graphene nanoplatelets has recently received special attention since it has fascinating thermal features such as superior thermal conductivity, plausible Brownian motion and thermophoresis phenomena [42] together with reasonably good stability when dispersed in a conventional coolant with poor thermal performance [43e45] such as water or ethylene glycol [46,47]. Thus, in the present work, graphene nanoplatelets are dispersed in methanol to enhance the thermo-physical properties of methanol, while also to employ the low-boiling point of methanol to further improve the thermal performance of the heat pipes inside the evacuated tubes at low temperatures. By doing this, the thermal efficiency of the collector is expected to be high due to the nucleate boiling heat transfer mechanism in the evaporator section. The influence of various operating parameters including the mass concentration of graphene in methanol, the filling ratio, the tilt angle of the collector, operating time and also the fluid flow rate within the collector on the THP of the collector was experimentally investigated and discussed.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation, quality tests and physical properties
sections.text:
To prepare the nanofluids, graphene nanoplatelets were purchased from USNANO and dispersed in methanol at mass fractions of 0.025%, 0.05%, 0.075% and 0.1%. To prepare the nanofluids, a desired mass of graphene nanoplatelets was weighted and dispersed within methanol together with the addition of Nonyl Phenol Etoxilate 400 (NPE400) as a surfactant to increase the stability of the nanofluid. The mixture was stirred at 250 rpm and sonicated for 10min at power throughput of 400W and the frequency of 40 kHz. Then, the prepared nanofluids were sent to the
laboratory to conduct the characterisation tests. Nanofluids were stable for 10 successive days due to the use of the ultrasonic and the presence of the surfactant. The stability period was almost the same for all mass fractions. After the stability period, nanofluid started creating clusters and graphene nanoplatelets were agglomerated. The agglomeration of the nanoplatelets increased the apparent density resulting in the formation of a deposition layer inside the container. The rate of deposition increased with the time spanning showing that the nanofluid is not suitable for the test 10 days after the preparation. Hence, we conducted the experiments within the first five days of the preparation to ensure that nanofluid is in its maximum stability. To identify this, time-settlement experiments were conducted such that the nanofluids were loaded into a transparent container and time was given to see the first signs of depositionwithin the container. For all the nanofluids, the deposition occurred at day 11. Also, without surfactant, the deposition occurred after 7 h of preparation. Hence, the addition of the surfactant was a key parameter influencing the stability of the nanofluid.
As can be seen in Fig. 1, to characterise the nanoplatelets, x-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and particle size tests were employed. The results of the XRD test revealed a monoclinic structure with the exact characteristic peaks for the graphene showing that there was no impurity in the structure of the graphene. Also, the SEM image showed that the average length of the agglomerated graphene nanoplatelets was 3 mm, an individual nanoplatelet's length was 123e424 nm and the thickness of the graphene nanoplatelets was 1.5e3 nm.

sections.heading: 2.2. The thermo-physical properties
sections.text:
Fig. 2 represents the thermo-physical properties of the
Fig. 1. Preparation and the characterisation of the
nanofluids measured at various mass concentrations of the graphene nanoplatelets. As can be seen, with an increase in the mass concentration of the nanofluid, the thermal conductivity, the heat capacity and the density of the nanofluid were increased. The maximum enhancement for thermal conductivity, viscosity and density was 19%, 10% and 3%, respectively. However, the heat capacity decreased with the increase in the mass concentration of the graphene nanoplatelets. The maximum reduction was observed at wt. %¼ 0.1 which was ~4% reduction in comparisonwith methanol.
graphene nanoplatelet/methanol nanofluids.
Notably, KD2 pro instrument (manufactured by Decagon, accuracy: 1% of reading value) was utilised to measure the thermal conductivity of the nanofluids. For the heat capacity and density, Thermogravimetric analyser (manufactured by Netzsch) and the density meter (manufactured by Cole-Parmer, accuracy: 1% of reading) and for viscosity, digital viscometer DV-I (manufactured by Brookfield, accuracy: 1% of reading) were employed. All instruments were calibrated with water and the agreement of 0.5%, 0.4%, 0.7% and 3% against the physical properties of water [48] was achieved for
thermal conductivity, viscosity, density and heat capacity, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Experimental setup
sections.text:
Fig. 3 shows a schematic representation of the evacuated tube used in the solar collector. The evacuated tube includes a heat pipe in the centre, which has an evaporator section, an adiabatic length and the condenser section located at the header tank. The working fluid of the heat pipewas replaced with nanofluid and the heat pipe was charged with nanofluids at various mass fractions. As can be seen, the solar irradiance is absorbed with the absorber and is transferred to the evaporator section inwhich the internal working fluid of the evacuated tube is evaporated with the nucleate boiling mechanism and due to the phase change, the heat is transported to the header tank. In the header tank, the thermal energy is delivered to cold water, while the working fluid (here nanofluid or methanol) inside the heat pipe is condensed and returned to the bottom of the heat pipe under a gravity-assisted falling film regime.
Fig. 4 shows a schematic representation of the test rig and also an image of the ETSC used in the present research. The evacuated tubes were charged with the nanofluids and deionised water was pumped from a heavily insulted tank into the solar collector with a centrifugal pump manufactured by DAB CO. (max. flow rate: 8 lit/ min). The flow rate of the flow in the collector's loop was controlled with an ultrasonic flowmeter connected to a valve and a servo. The temperature of the tank was monitored with a PID controller and
of the evacuated solar thermal collector used in the present research.
also a thermostat bath to ensure a back-to-back comparison between the data obtained for each test. The inlet and the outlet temperatures of the solar collector were constantly monitored with two k-type thermocouples connected to a data logger with data collection frequency of 1 kHz. The outlet of the collector was chilled with a double-pipe heat exchanger connected to the thermostat bath to ensure that the temperature of the tank remains constant during the experiments. Notably, a bypass cycle was utilised to further adjust the flow rate within the system. This ensures a very accurate flow rate adjustment within the system.
The accurate geographical coordination of the place was 27.19 latitude and 56.28 longitude and it was situated at elevation 8.9m above the sea level. Since the location takes advantage of almost 298 sunny days within a year, the experiments were conducted there to ensure that the maximum solar share can be achieved. The experiments were conducted on 6th to 9th August 2018 which had the same solar irradiance profile.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Data reduction and uncertainty analysis
sections.text:
Mass fraction of a nanofluid is a key parameter, which influences its heat transfer characteristics. To measure the mass concentration of the nanofluid, following equation was used:
wt:% ¼ wnp wbf
(1)
Here, wnp and wbf stand for the weight of the nanoparticles and the base fluid, respectively. Also, the filling ratio of the heat pipes in evacuated tubes is another key operating parameter, which influence the operation of the evacuated tube solar thermal collector and is defined as the volumetric ratio of the nanofluid charged into the heat pipe to the total volume of the evaporator section of the heat pipe:
Filling ratioð%Þ ¼ volume of NanoFluid volume of evaporator
(2)
To measure the cumulative thermal energy absorbed by the thermal collector, at each hour, the thermal energy absorbed by the collector was measured and the following correlation was used to obtain the daily cumulative thermal energy absorbed by the collector:
Qcum: ¼ ðt¼24 hr
t¼1 hr Qcol::dt (3)
and
Qcol: ¼ _m Cp TET ;out TET ;in
(4)
Here, Cp is the heat capacity of the working fluid in the collector loop, T is the temperature of the working fluid in the loop, “ET, in” and “ETout” stand for the inlet and the outlet of the collector obtained with k-type thermocouples (accuracy: ±1 C). Also, _m is the
mass flow rate of the fluid in the collector's loop, which can be calculated with the following equation:
_m ¼ r _Q (5)
Here, r is the density of theworking fluid (deionisedwater) and _Q is the volumetric flow rate of the working fluid, which can be obtained from the ultrasonic flow meter (Flownetix, accuracy: 1% of the reading value). Thus, the thermal efficiency of the collector can be obtained with the following equation:
h ¼ _m Cp
TET;out TET ;in
G Ac (6)
Here, G stands for the solar irradiance normal to the collector, and Ac is the area of the collector.
The uncertainty analysis was conducted following the procedure introduced by Kline-McClintock [49], which employs the total uncertainty of the instruments and also the devices used for the measurement of the parameters [16]: DR ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi vR vx1 Dx1 2 þ vR vx2 Dx2 2 þ vR vx3 Dx3 þ ::: s (7)
In Eq. (7), R is a function of the independent variables of x1, x2, x3, …, xn, R¼ R (x1, x2, x3, …, xn), and Dx1; Dx2; Dx3; :::Dxn are the values for the uncertainty of the independent variables, which are achieved through the uncertainty of themeasurement instruments. All the uncertainty values have been given in Table 1. Hence, the total uncertainty for the efficiency measurement is ±3.5%.
Table 2 presents the specifications of the evacuated solar thermal collector used in the present research.

sections.heading: 3.1. Solar irradiance and ambient temperature
sections.text:
Fig. 5 represents the dependence on time of the solar irradiance and also the hourly average ambient temperature of the location of the experiments. As can be seen, the highest solar irradiance was observed between 10:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. reaching 920W/m2 at 1:00 p.m. The solar irradiance represented in Fig. 5 was obtained at the hottest day in midsummer (6th August 2018) to maximise the solar thermal energy absorbed by the collector. The same trend for solar irradiance was also observed for other days in summer and other seasons, meaning that the highest solar irradiance was in midday, however, the highest value of solar irradiance varied from 410W/m2 in winter to 520W/m2 and 780W/m2 in winter, autumn and spring, respectively. As can also be seen, the hourly mean ambient temperature followed the trend obtained for the solar irradiance such that the highest ambient temperaturewas obtained between 10:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. too. The lowest and the highest temperature readings were 27.5 C and 41 C, respectively. Also, the temperature rectilinearly increased with the time spanning. Hence,
.
the experiments were conducted from 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. to maximise the utilisation of the available solar irradiance in the region.
3.2. Tilt angle and filling ratio
Figs. 6 and 7 represent the variation of the cumulative energy absorption from the thermal collector with the installation tilt angle of the collector and the filling ratio of the heat pipes in the evacuated tubes. As can be seen in Fig. 6, with an increase in the tilt angle of the collector, the cumulative energy absorption initially increased reaching 15MJ/day and then decreased with an increase in the tilt angle of the collector. The highest cumulative thermal energy absorption belonged to the tilt angle of 35 (the red rectangular), while the lowest thermal energy was absorbed with the installation tilt angles of 40 and higher. Interestingly, these findings are in accordance with the results reported by Refs. [50e52].
As can be seen in Fig. 7, with an increase in the filling ratio of the heat pipes from 10% to 60%, the cumulative thermal energy absorbed by the collector increased from 14.2MJ/day to 15.2MJ/ day, and suddenly decreases to 14.5MJ/day at filling ratio of 70%. This behaviour can be attributed to the trade-off between the space available inside the heat pipe and also the heat capacity of the working fluid (m Cp). With an increase in the filling ratio of the working fluid, the total heat capacity of the working fluid increases, while the space available for transporting the vapour inside the heat pipe significantly decreased. Hence, there is an optimumvalue
for the filling ratio, in which the thermal transport within the heat pipe is maximised, while the heat capacity of the working fluid is still plausible. Notably, for the tilt angle value, there is another trade-off between some parameters including gravity, residence time of the working fluid in the evaporator section and the area of the collector exposed to the solar irradiance. With an increase in the tilt angle of the collector, the gravity force facilitates the return of the working fluid to the evaporator section, which in turn decreases the area exposed to the solar irradiance and also decreases the residence time of the working fluid in the condenser section. Hence for both parameters, depending on the type of the working fluid, the optimum value should be experimentally identified.

sections.heading: 3.3. Flow rate of water
sections.text:
Fig. 8 show the dependence of the thermal efficiency of the collector with the time of the day for various working fluids including graphene-methanol nanofluids and pure methanol at various mass concentrations and for different flow rates. As can be seen from Fig. 8, with the time spanning, the thermal efficiency of the solar thermal collector increased reaching to an efficiency peak
at 1:00 p.m. (e.g. 0.7 at FR¼ 3 lit/min) and decreased to 0.1 at 8:00 p.m. Also, with an increase in the flow rate of the collector's loop, the thermal efficiency was increased. For example, at 10:00 a.m., for flow rate of 1 lit/min, the thermal efficiency was 0.31 reaching to 0.5 at FR¼ 3 lit/min for the given time of the day. It is worth saying that at FR¼ 3 lit/min, the value of the thermal efficiency reached 0.7 and 0.95 for methanol and nanofluid at wt. %¼ 0.1, respectively at 1:00 p.m. This is because with an increase in the temperature of the collector, the thermo-physical properties of the working fluid especially thermal conductivity is improved and also phenomena such as Brownianmotion and thermophoresis effect are intensified, which in turn increase the thermal efficiency of the collector. Note that, the Brownian motion and also the thermophoresis effect both boost the THP of the heat pipe, especially in the evaporator section in which the nucleate boiling is the dominant mechanism of heat transfer.
Fig. 9 presents the dependence of the thermal efficiency of the solar collector on the reduced temperature ((Ti-Ta)/G) for methanol and graphene-methanol nanofluid at two different mass concentrations of 0.05% and 0.1% (Ti and Ta are the inlet and ambient temperatures). As can be seen, with an increase in the flow rate, the value of the thermal efficiency of the collector increased. Also, the presence of graphene nanoplatelets improved the thermal efficiency of the collector in comparison with methanol. For example, at FR¼ 1 lit/min, at reduced temperature of 0.02 (m2. K/W), the efficiency of the solar collector is 0.37, while it is 0.41 and 0.52 for nanofluids at wt. %¼ 0.05 and 0.1, respectively. This shows that the presence of graphene nanoplatelets can potentially improve the Brownian motion and also the nucleate boiling heat transfer within the evaporator, which in turn improved the thermal efficiency of the system. Notably, for both flow rates, a rectilinear trend for thermal efficiency versus reduced temperature was observed.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present research, an experimental study was conducted to assess the thermal performance of a solar collector equipped with evacuated tubes working with graphene-methanol nanofluids and the following conclusion were made:
Using nonyl phenol ethoxylate 400 (NPE 400), the stability of graphene in methanol was guaranteed for 10 successive days. Also, graphene nanoplatelets improved the thermal conductivity of methanol (enhanced by 20% over that of measured for methanol), which was attributed to the improvement in the Brownian motion and thermophoresis effects. The maximum thermal efficiency of 95% was achieved well above the average thermal performance of the current collectors working with conventional working fluid (e.g. 65-70% for an acetone-based evacuated solar collector). With an increase in the mass concentrations of the nanofluid, the thermal efficiency of the thermal collector was enhanced. The highest thermal efficiency of the collector was 0.95 achieved at wt. %¼ 0.1 and also the maximum temperature difference of 20 C was obtained at FR¼ 3 lit/min. Assessment of the collector showed that the value of the tilt angle and also the filling ratio highly influenced the thermal energy accumulated by the collector. Therefore, the best value for the filling ratio of the heat pipes was 60% and the optimum tilt angle value was 35 .
Overall, the graphene-methanol nanofluid seems to be a plausible option to be utilised inside the heat pipes and can improve the thermal efficiency of the ETSCs. However, a technoeconomic assessment is highly recommended to be conducted with the view to identify the economic viability of the system. Also, further research is required to improve the technology readiness level towards the commercialisation of the nanofluids inside the ETSCs.
Nomenclature
All the symbols have been fully explained in the text.
Conflicts of interest
The authors of the present work declare that there is no conflict of interest regarding the paper.

referenceMentions.context: Renewable energy is one of the potential solutions to address the challenges associated with the environmental pollution and climate change due to the combustion of fossil fuels [1].

With a continuous increase in the world population and also the limitation of the fossil fuels, special attention has recently been paid to renewable energy resources no only to address the energy crisis [2], but also to decrease the rate of emission of carbon dioxide and greenhouse gases to atmosphere.
industrial applications, which can provide thermal energy from solar irradiance for various applications [10,11].

Evacuated solar thermal collector is an apparatus, which uses the heat pipe technology to absorb the solar energy and transfer it to another heat transfer fluid using the phase change mechanism inside the heat pipe [6].
Therefore, thermal performance of the heat pipe is relatively high in comparisonwith the convective systems [12].

Nanofluid was first introduced by Aragon National Laboratory (ANL) [17], and so far, much effort has been made to utilise nanofluids in various thermal applications including solar thermal energy [12,18e20].
[31] used aqueous nanofluids to increase the THP of a solar thermal collector.

[40], it was found that the carbon nanotube dispersed inwater has reasonably good thermal properties to improve the THP of a flat heat pipe.

[41] investigated the potential application of CuO and alumina nanofluids in a heat pipe employed in a ETSC and found that the presence of the nanoparticles can decrease the temperature profile and suppress the heat transfer mechanism in the evaporator from boiling to evaporation, while decreasing the total thermal resistance of the heat pipe.

Graphene nanoplatelets has recently received special attention since it has fascinating thermal features such as superior thermal conductivity, plausible Brownian motion and thermophoresis phenomena [42] together with reasonably good stability when dispersed in a conventional coolant with poor thermal performance [43e45] such as water or ethylene glycol [46,47].

metadata.abstractText: In the present article, we report the results of several experiments conducted on the thermal performance and efficiency of an evacuated tube solar collector (ETSC). The heat pipes were charged with graphene-methanol nanofluid and the effect of various operating conditions including the installation tilt angle of the collector, the value of the filling ratio, the mass fraction of graphene nanoplatelets and the flow rate of the collector's loop on the thermal efficiency of the collector was experimentally investigated. Results showed that the presence of graphene nanoplatelets improved the thermal conductivity of methanol (enhanced by 19% at wt. %1⁄4 0.1), while the heat capacity of the nanofluid decreased by a decrease in the mass fraction of the graphene (decreased by 4% at wt. %1⁄4 0.1). Also, it was identified that the thermal efficiency of the solar thermal collector reached 95% with nanofluid at wt. %1⁄4 0.1 and at flow rate of 3 lit/min. The largest temperature difference between the inlet and the outlet of the collector belonged to the graphene-methanol nanofluid at wt. %1⁄4 0.1, which represented the lowest heat capacity. Also, the daily thermal energy absorption of the collector was the highest at the tilt angle and the filling ratio values of 35 and 60%, respectively. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
